text:
I noticed that the soname of the libapr library changed in httpd-2.0.46. It is
now libapr-0.so.0 instead of libapr.so.0. Does the new 2.0.46 version introduce
incompatibilities? Or is this specific to my system somehow? I'm running linux with:
libtool-1.4.3
autoconf-2.56
automake-1.7.1
creator: panlinux@gmail.com
jwoolley@apache.org
text:
We didn't change it intentionally as far as I'm aware, no.  It might be a libtool issue (I belive we 
upgraded to libtool 1.5 with this release).  There shouldn't be any binary incompatibilities with 
the previous release.

The names of apr and apr-util changed with Apache 2.0.45, from libapr.so* and
libaprutil.so* to libapr-0.so* and libaprutil-0.so*.  The "-0" indicates the APR
major version number.  It was deliberate.

I too was suspicious and raised the issue prior to 2.0.45's release, but nobody
considered it a problem and, in fact, Apache DSO modules which are built with
apxs, or in a manner compatible with apxs, don't refer to libapr or libaprutil
directly anyway.

Unfortunately, it turns out that a few non-ASF DSO modules on AIX are built in
such a way that they refer to those libraries, so for them a symlink is
necessary (libapr.so->libapr-0.so and libaprutil.so->libaprutil-0.so).
creator: trawick@apache.org

Hah, guess that shows how good a memory *I* have, which is to say none at all.  =)  I actually do 
remember that discussion now that you mention it, Jeff...
creator: jwoolley@apache.org
panlinux@gmail.com
text:
Well, 2.0.45 still uses the old name here, but when I compile 2.0.45 in the same
environment, then the soname changes.

Anyway, the main reason I raised this question is because we ship subversion,
which links with libapr and breaks if I attempt to upgrade apache to 2.0.46
without some hacking (namely, a symlink until subversion is recompiled).

And since you guys make a hard effort to not break compatibility since 2.0.42, I
thought I should mention this.
